justification: “Pupillometry … is suitable for tracking how effort changes on a moment-to-moment basis before, during, and after the listening process,” indicating listening effort is indexed by pupil-dilation measures.
The paper notes that “pupillometry—the measurement of changes in pupil dilation—has been used as an objective measure of cognitive load (Zekveld et al. 2018; Beatty 1982a).”
“Baseline pupil size can be a reliable indicator of optimal states for sensory detection … and lapses of attention,” showing that baseline diameter is used to index arousal and attention.

Referring to word-recall work, the article states that “increased pupil dilation during novel word exposure was associated with better learning … the dilation response could be considered to be a memory-strength signal.”

Under ‘Pupillary signs of fatigue’ the authors write that fatigue appears as “reduction of phasic responses … and decreased pupil size following a long block of tiring work,” linking pupil measures to fatigue assessment.
